clinical_study.brief_title: A Randomized Prospective Clinical Trial of Fel d 1 Peptide Immunotherapy
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Peptide Immunotherapy on Frequency, Memory Phenotype, Chemokine Receptor Expression and Markers of Regulatory T Cell Function Among Allergen-Specific T Cells

lead_sponsor.agency: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID)

clinical_study.source: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID)

brief_summary.textblock: The goal of this study is to identify changes in cells that are related to the treatment with Cat-PAD (ToleroMune Cat).

detailed_description.textblock: Cat-PAD is an experimental cat allergy vaccine and has been studied to determine if it can reduce symptom scores of participants exposed to cat allergen. To study how the vaccine causes changes in the immune system, the researchers plan to evaluate changes in the blood (genes and proteins) and urine in response to the Cat-PAD vaccine.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in the area under the curve (AUC) from 0 to 6 hour for total nasal symptom score (TNSS).
primary_outcome.time_frame: Following nasal allergen challenge , one year after initiation of peptide immunotherapy.
primary_outcome.description: This outcome will be analyzed using analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) where the difference in mean AUC between the untreated and treated groups will be compared while statistically controlling for the effects of the baseline AUC.

arm_group.description: Subjects will be treated with four monthly doses of Cat-PAD, a peptide immunotherapy product consisting of Fel d 1 synthetic peptide immunoregulatory epitopes (SPIRE).
Subjects will be treated with 4 monthly doses of Placebo.

intervention.description: The assigned study intervention will be administered by intradermal injection into the flexor surface of the forearm.
